casebody.data:
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee v. Martin PADILLA, Defendant-Appellant. No. 08-40272

Summary Calendar.

United States Court of Appeals, Fifth Circuit. April 13, 2009. James Lee Turner, Assistant U.S. Attorney, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Southern District of Texas, Houston, TX, for Plaintiff-Appellee. Martin Padilla, Oxford, WI, pro se. Before JONES, Chief Judge, and STEWART and OWEN, Circuit Judges. PER CURIAM: *

In October 2003, Martin Padilla, federal prisoner # 19691-179, was convicted by jury verdict of possession with intent to distribute an amount in excess of five kilograms of cocaine and was sentenced to 121 months of imprisonment and five years of supervised release. In February 2008, at a time when he had no actions pending, Padilla filed a motion requesting production of the grand jury testimony from his criminal case. Padilla has not provided a valid jurisdictional basis for his motion. See United States v. Carvajal, 989 F.2d 170, 170 (5th Cir.1993). Even if it is assumed that a jurisdictional basis for the motion exists, the district court properly denied that motion because Padilla failed to show a particularized need for the grand jury transcripts. See United States v. Miramontez, 995 F.2d 56, 59-60 (5th Cir.1993). The district court’s judgment is AFFIRMED.

Pursuant to 5th Cut. R. 47.5, the court has determined that this opinion should not be published and is not precedent except under the limited circumstances set forth in 5th Cir. R. 47.5.4.
